g.text: Department of Applied Chemistry, Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University, 3-14-1 Hiyoshi, Kohoku-ku, Yokohama
nanocrystals (NCs) are excellent candidates for green-emitting
phosphors in wide color gamut displays; however, a detailed
investigation of their photoluminescence (PL) properties based on
the halide composition has been missing. In this work, we report a
fundamental investigation of the changes in the PL properties of
NCs. The PL color of the NCs, which were prepared
by a hot-injection method, changed from green to red with increasing
). Almost ideal green emission close to the
chromaticity coordinates of the green vertex of the BT.2020 standard
was achieved by appropriately substituting iodide ions for bromide
NCs. However, the PL peak width of the
0.5 was 0.127 eV, which was broader than the
0.105 eV peak width of the monohalide CsPbBr
NCs. This phenomenon should be due to the compositional inhomogeneity
NCs. On the other hand, the PL quantum yield (PLQY) for the monohalide CsPbBr
increased to 0.5. This result may be attributed to lattice distortion by the diﬀerence in the
ionic radii of bromide and iodide. Improvements in the compositional inhomogeneity and lattice distortion would enhance the
color purity of the green emission and the PLQY, respectively, of the CsPb(Br
Displays using patterned red-green-blue emitters without color
ﬁlters can realize excellent color purity and a wider color
reproduction range with higher emission eﬃciencies compared
to those exploiting a white backlight passed through color
In the former method, a blue light-emitting diode
(LED) is used as a blue light source, and green- and red-
emitting phosphors are excited by the blue light to obtain
green and red colors, respectively. BT.2020, which is a next-
generation color standard for 4/8 K broadcasting, has a
signiﬁcantly larger range in the green than the conventional
green-emitting phosphors with extremely high color purities
are required for the green emitters in displays. Traditional
cannot realize the required color purity because of their
unnecessary PL peaks outside of the green region and broad
PL peak widths. CdSe quantum dots (QDs) are the most
commonly used nanophosphors that exhibit visible emission,
therefore, other visible-emitting QDs such as CuInS
InP have been identiﬁed as Cd-free alternative materials.
Green-emitting InP QDs are one of the candidates for
application in wide color gamut displays; however, the full
width at half-maximum (FWHM) of their green PL peak is
50 nm, which is too broad to satisfy the green range of the
In recent years, all-inorganic perovskite semiconductor
shown great development, triggered by a report from
The PL wavelength of these NCs can be
tuned in the visible region between 410 and 700 nm by
changing the halide composition, and smaller FWHMs of the
PL peak with excellent PL quantum yields (PLQYs) of 50
PLQYs, core/shell structures, such as CdSe/ZnS QDs
were not needed. The outstanding PL
therefore, numerous studies on their synthetic methods,
applications, such as in LEDs and photodetectors,
NCs have a great potential to
realize green emission for wide color gamut displays that satisfy
the BT.2020 standard because of their highly pure PL color
